Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Tectonic and climatic forcing of hydrological systems in the southern Great Basin: Implications for ancient and future aquatic system resilience
Award.AbstractNarration:
The southern Great Basin is among the most arid regions in North America. It has almost no
perennial streams, but does have >1,000 springs. These springs are islands of aquatic habitat
in an ocean of desert. Remarkably, many of these isolated springs contain diverse aquatic
ecosystems and even endemic species of fish, spring snails, and other aquatic organisms. The
presence of many aquatic species that can only survive in water is evidence that the springs
are remnants of a perennial drainage system, and the presence of endemic species requiring
intervals in the million-year range for genetic divergence are evidence that at least some
of these springs have never desiccated over the geological time scale. Aquatic biogeographical
patterns thus inform the geological and hydrological history of the region.

This is a project to expand the already-large regional biogeographical database and to use the combined
new and preexisting data to test models of tectonic and paleohydrological evolution of the
southern Great Basin. The PIs will focus on two timescales: that of the extensional breakup of
the region from the late Miocene to the present and that of glacial/interglacial climate cycles.
Extensive work has been done to understand the extensional history of the region, which started
in the eastern portion of the study area at ~14 Ma and migrated westward to the Sierra Nevada
front, driven by plate-boundary dynamics. They will simulate this evolution using a regional
quasi-3D kinematic/tectonic-geomorphic-hydrologic coupled model that fully couples movement
along faults, mass distribution, magmatism, isostatic compensation and flexural deformation
with hydrology and surface geomorphic processes, including erosion and deposition. The extensional
fragmentation of the hydrological system will be studied and groundwater flow, necessary to
simulate the resulting development of springs, will be an integral part of the regional tectonic-geomorphic-hydrologic model.
.
Modeled paleohydrologic histories will be tested against biotic data (aquatic biota inventories,
microbial and macrofaunal DNA, and genetic divergence times) with island biogeography theory.
The PIs will test for relations of hydrologic fragmentation chronology with endemic species and
for ecosystem diversity with spring resilience, as inferred from groundwater ages and climatically
driven modeling. They will use these results to assess and improve their tectonic/paleohydrologic models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our lab’s portion of this collaborative study focused on desert springs in the U.S. Great Basin (Nevada and California) and their associated microorganisms within the context of complex Earth-system evolution in the region. Together with a team of hydrogeologists, we sampled over 80 springs in remote areas and collected data on the hydrological and geochemical setting (e.g., spring water age and chemistry), microorganisms in the bulk water and sediment, and benthic invertebrates. To date, this is by far the largest study of microorganisms inhabiting desert springs. There were three significant scientific outcomes. (1) Great Basin springs host extremely diverse microbial communities. We have sequenced over 10 million 16S rRNA genes from our springs and they represent over 100,000 unique sequence variants, which may be roughly equivalent to species. Comparison of these numbers indicate that these microbial populations are more than three-fold more diverse than comparable datasets from geothermal springs and freshwater systems, and much more diverse than animal microbiome samples. (2) There is a high degree of endemism in these springs. Only ~4% of microbial species are found in all three of the focus areas of the study (Owens Valley, Death Valley, Amargosa Valley), with ~15% being found in two of the focus areas, leaving more than 80% of the species to be endemic to one focus area. This pattern is likely tied to the evolution of landforms in the region through tectonic activity and aridification since the Ice Age, and suggests that together these springs hold enormous microbial diversity. It is likely that many species of microorganisms live nowhere else on Earth. (3) Elevation is a major factor correlating with microbial community composition. This is true regardless of host rock. In particular, high-elevation springs are distinct from low-elevation springs regardless of whether they are in carbonate-dominated ranges (e.g., Spring Mountains, Panamint Mountains, White Mountains) or granitic systems (i.e., Sierra Nevada). Elevation correlates with lots of other factors such as temperature and markers of geochemical evolution (e.g., specific conductivity).

 

This project provided funding for a first-generation, female Ph.D. student. She presented her work at several international conferences and regionally to a variety of non-scientists, including a community workshop in Tecopa, California that was focused on water resources in the desert. Five different undergraduate students have experienced science first-hand though participation in this project. Three of these students have enrolled in graduate programs and one is investigating graduate programs. Our project has also reached a number of high-school science teachers, who are working to integrate content and conceptual frameworks for analysis of large data sets into their classrooms.
